Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Commercialization of Bio-Design Automation Software for Synthetic Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be to develop algorithms and software to address basic and fundamental design automation tasks in synthetic biology. The goal is to fundamentally change the way that biological designs are conceived, designed, and physically created. The tools and techniques proposed introduce a new way of thinking about biological engineering that will transform the current biological procedures from an "artisanal" craft confined to small niche research projects to an engineering discipline based on modular parts, characterization data, requirements, rule-based design, optimized planning, and standardized automation, all capable of scaling up to support the complexity of future applications, and is the first to do so in an end-to-end manner. Further, the proposed work is a core enabler for the synthetic biology discipline that has the potential to assist the biomanufacturing industry turn resources and expertise into products.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop algorithms and software for the design, planning, assembly, and analysis of synthetic biological constructs. The proposed activities will bring three software tools closer to commercial deployment: Tools for genetic design, assembly planning, and rule mining. This proposal addresses the fundamental overall problem of designing, building, and optimizing a network of genes that produce a specified behavior in an organism. The proposed project will further develop and tailor software algorithms and tools for the combinatorial design of genetic networks using graph theory. It will extend algorithms and tools for planning the DNA assembly of large sets of designs using advanced dynamic programming algorithms, and it will integrate data mining approaches for learning design rules for optimizing genetic networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this award (SBIR Phase I: Commercialization of Bio-Design Automation Software for Synthetic Biology) are a set of software tools for automating the design and construction of synthetic biological systems. These tools include a database to track DNA "parts", a viewer/editor to examine and modify these parts, small programs and abstracted grammars to manipulate parts automatically, and automated assembly programs for combining these DNA parts to generate larger, composite parts. This software comprises a cohesive suite of web tools accessible from all standard web browsers. The codebase has been curated with professional development practices and standards. It has been designed to faciliate continued evolution of the product for additional or changing customer requirements.

During the combined Phase 1 and Phase 1B project timeline we have invested significant resources developing real relationships with customers who will and do use our software. As a result, previously academic-only ideas have been incorporated into our algorithms and software tools have been transitioned to the commercial software realm. This not only serves to vet the technology but also creates a paradigm shift in the industry to be more forward thinking with regard to the integration of engineering principles into a largely scientific discipline. As industry becomes more reliant on computing, the more expansive the opportunity space for interacting with these types of services becomes. This opens scientific avenues previously unexplored, creating careers at the confluence of computation, engineering, and biology, and providing a fertile environment for novel biological progress.

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2016
Modified by: Kevin G Leshane
